3-4 = All game-figures in Trollshaws move 4 fields back
5-6 = Nothing happens
179456.name: Der Hobbit: Eine unerwartete Reise: Azog – Die Mini-Erweiterung
boardgameexpansion: Der Hobbit: Eine unerwartete Reise – Das Spiel zum Film

179457.description:
Second game in the series with different themes including movies, music, novels etc.

There is letter in one side of the card and theme (bands, actors, TV-Series etc.) in another side of the card. Turn around top card and be the first to say something that matches the theme from one card starting the letter from another card and You get the card as a point. If nobody can´t say anything or there is a tie the card is kept for the next round.
If the deck runs out the player with the most points is the winner.
179457.name: Tark Mees Taskus 2

179458.name: Luddit
179458.description:
Name: Luddit. Mix of "Ludit" (Latin: "He plays") and "Luddite" (-"against the machines"- cause the ultimate purpose of this game -project- is to be impossible to solve by computers; i really hope some of you would want to join forces with me in this holy crusade ).

Characteristics: the leading objective was (is) to make a game which could be as difficult as possible to solve for the computers (maybe...impossible?). By the moment, contrarily to my interest, the rules are by far not simple, ...im trying to improve that. I tried to achieve complexity by giving to the game a very chaotical and recursive nature. The board is defined in order to try to let an action to have infinite repercussion in the unfolding of the game. Its notable that, strictly speaking, the board doesnt have borders (as may be seen in the rules), so there is no "preferential positions". Its interesting to note that the definition of "loop" does lead to literally infinite possibilities of combination in some cases (its definition is precisely the feature that has leadme to think that this game can be much more than just "dificult" for the computer...). And its interesting to note that wining implies to reduce this possibilities to one, that is, to reduce the number of possibilities, which is the thermodynamic definition of negative entropy. So you have to play with chaos to bring order.

Equipment:
- 9x9 Torus board with 9x9 square grid (a standard 9x9 GO board can be used, obeying the mechanic of the torus board), 18xwhite stones, 18xblack stones. (i decided this size mostly to facilitate initial playtesting. Of course the game can be played in larger boards)

Rules:

1 - Game is played on the intersections. Adjacency is defined as orthogonal and diagonal (i.e. every intersection point has 8 adjacent points).

2 - There can’t be more than 18 total stones on the board at any time.

3 - We will call "piece" to every single stone or loop. A piece is of the color of a player if every stone that composes it is of the color of that player. A piece is "at range" of another if they shares at least one of their adjacent intersections.

4 - We will call "loop" to every group of pieces (regardless of color) where every piece is at range of at least another two pieces of the group (nothing prevents loops for sharing pieces). Its implied by the rule, but to clarify: If a piece A is composed by all the stones that composes a piece B, and viceversa, then A and B are the same piece, and B cant be considered has "another" piece for A, and viceversa.

5 - We will say that a piece is "conditioned" to a player if its of the player color or if any group of pieces (regardless of color) that are at range of that piece conforms a loop.

6 - A player makes a "move" by either:
a) Taking a single stone of his color from the outside of the board and placing it in an empty place over the board.
b) Removing a piece that is conditioned to him from the board.
c) Removing a piece that is conditioned to him from the board, and then placing it back on an empty space on the board. If the removed piece is a loop, it has to remain a loop when placed back on the board.

7 - At the start of the game the board is empty. Each player is assigned a color. Black plays first. Then both players play alternately. In his turn, a player can do one or two moves, if he has no legal move to perform the game ends, and he loses.

boardgamehonor: 2015 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
2016 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
179460.description:
Stronghold is a two-player game telling the story of a siege. Players take opposing sides: one has to defend the stronghold, and the other has to break into the castle as soon as possible. The game board represents the stronghold itself as well as the surrounding terrain, where enemy forces are placed and whence they proceed to the walls.

The defender has a small number of soldiers manning the walls, while the invader has an infinite legion of attacking creatures. A desperate fight takes place every single turn. The invaders build war machines, equip their soldiers, train them, and use black magic rituals to achieve victory. Meanwhile, defenders repair walls, build cannons, train soldiers, and do everything they can to hold the castle as long as possible.

If the invader manages to break into the castle before the end of seven rounds, they win; otherwise the defender wins.

This second edition of Stronghold features:

• Ten objective cards for the invader and ten hidden defense plan cards for the defender; each objective encourages the invader to consider a particular move, while each defense plan shows the defender different ways to surprise the invader
• Shorter gameplay than the first edition, with attackers being placed on the board during set-up
• Gameplay limited to two players only, replacing the team rules in the first edition
• Streamlined rules and an enhanced rulebook
• Improved components, such as a larger game board and new, drab, brown artwork
179460.name: Stronghold (2nd edition)
boardgamepodcastepisode: 43: Patchwork Stronghold
Cult of the New Board Game Podcast Episode 008 – T.I.M.E Stories vs Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective
Ep 28 Stronghold Games Publishing With Stephen Buonocore
Episode 121: Mythos Tales, Far Space Foundry and Horror Films turned Board Game
Episode 20 - Pandemic Legacy Review (With and Without Spoilers!)
Essen 2015 - Portal Games
Essen 2015 - Stronghold Games
Gaming Rules! – Podcast 20
MOBG 40 7th Scythe 24-10-15

RDTN Episode 77 – Fortress Around Your Heart: A visit from the Podfather – Stephen Buonocore, Game Day with Pete and Scott
RDTN Episode 81 – Come Together: BGG Con Review – Suzanne Sheldon, Matt Evans, Chaz Marler, and Joel Eddy
RDTN Episode 83 – Fortress Around Your Heart – Stronghold 2nd Edition Review and a bunch more
The Game Pit: Episode 71 - Spiel ‘16 Council Chamber with Stephen Buonocore
The Long View - Quick Looks #15
Vox Republica 135: Gaming Difficulty

179461.name: Mythic Solutions
179461.description:
Publisher's Blurb

These are the solutions you're looking for!

Mythic Solutions analyzes the challenges of implementing the mythic rules for the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game and offers you no-nonsense solutions to address them. The mythic rules have been with us for almost two years, and with a wealth of play experience we can see areas where rules interact together in ways that have the potential to unbalance gameplay. The mythic rules are supposed to break from convention and allow players and GMs to creatively violate the expectations of how the game usually works, but sometimes those alterations─especially in combination with each other─go a bit too far.

Mythic Solutions is a 26-page supplement that explores the challenges of action economy, the nova problem, stacking multiplies, single ability focus, rapid recovery, bypassing immunity and resistance, unlimited caster versatility, and rocket tag, or there is no kill like overkill. The masters of mythic at Legendary Games explain rules rationales and concepts and offer an array of alternate rules to deal with the most problematic elements in the mythic rule set like Mythic Vital Strike, wild arcana, foe-biter legendary weapons, and more! If you'd like to get the most out of the mythic rules but are worried about balance or numbers escalating out of control, worry no more! Nobody knows mythic like Legendary Games, and these Mythic Solutions will definitely help Make Your Game Legendary!

179462.name: Drongo: Planet of Peril
179462.description:
From publisher blurb:

Drongo, on the edge of Shade Space, is a terrifying world that offers unlimited opportunity for the brave few and lingering painful death for all but the strongest. Any who would tarry here must fear the possibility of being summoned before the Bone Throne of the mad Tyrant and called to account for their presence in his demesne.

A campaign setting for OSR SciFi games.

This version is specifically written for the WhiteStar rule-set.

179463.name: Small Packages
179463.description:
From publisher blurb:

Their story started with their death, but there is always hope, and even destiny can be spurned with enough determination. This is the tale of the tribe too gentle to survive in Everglow, and how they might have pulled through the dark times that led to their end. Play a short leg yourself or incorporate them into your existing game.

New feats, racial stats, pony satyr rules, spells and more all designed for short leg ponies!

179464.name: The City of Judas
179464.description:
From publisher blurb:

In this dark fantasy, sword&sorcery setting you are a member of the Brotherhood of the Iron Fist, a company of mercenaries who work in the shadows in the City of Judas.
The setting focuses around an imaginary Jerusalem, heart of flaming religious crusades between the church of Christ and the cult of Judas, with the new sept of the Book of Q getting stronger each day. Which side will you choose to fight for?
But that's not enough: evil monsters, dark demons and wicked minions will try to partake in the feast.

City of Judas is an Apocalypse World dark fantasy hack, for 3 to 6 players.
The manual contains a set of new moves, additional mechanics such as the Advantage Die, original combat mechanics, ten different playbooks of Iron Fist mercenaries for your players.
The GM section includes GM Principles and GM Moves, a guide to the first session and character creation, elements for missions and fronts, and a complete set of wild monsters and demons.

179465.name: Universal Adventures Celestial Invocations
179465.description:
From publisher blurb:

The powers of death and darkness are on the rise. What hope does humanity have in the wake of such overwhelming evil?

Invoke the power of the Celestial Realms with Celestial Invocations! Universal Adventures Celestial Invocations is a set of 54 cards, each describing a clerical invocation, including range, duration, effect, and so forth. Useable by any clerical-type that serves a patron of order and light, Celestial Invocations can be used with any RPG, including Ogres and Underworlds, Swords and Savagery and future RPG’s from NRP. Bolster your comrades and blast the forces of death and darkness with Celestial Invocations!

179466.name: Everyman Unchained: Monk Archetypes II
179466.description:
From publisher blurb:

You've unchained your monk, now make him shine with Everyman Unchained: Monk Archetypes II! This product by Everyman Gaming, LLC finishes the good work of its predecessor by updated a variety of official Pathfinder RPG archetypes to make them compatible with the unchained monk from Pathfinder Roleplaying Game: Pathfinder Unchained as well as several archetypes from other Everyman Gaming products. Some of the archetypes that you will discover within Everyman Unchained: Monk Archetypes II include:

The Golden Devil Master, a member of a female monastery that studies the fighting styles of barbed devils to learn to deliver painful strikes of her own.
The Kyuubi Visionary, a kitsune monk who learns to manipulate his ki so as to help him unlock the secret of manifesting additional tails.
The Monk of a Million Lives, a samsaran monk who enters a zen state where he can draw upon the abilities and experiences of all of his prior reincarnations.
The Monk of the Seven Forms, a monk devoted to an esoteric fighting style that strives to perfect his body.
An update to the Cracking the Code sidebar that now includes a conversion for standard monk archetypes that trade the maneuver training class feature.
And much, much more!

179467.name: Heraldric Devices
179467.description:
From publisher blurb:

Purple Duck Storerooms are short pdfs of experimental material. Spell components have lost of their luster over the years. They are a forgotten piece of non-equipment due to one culprit--the spell component pouch.

Within these pages you will find a new type of magic item, the heraldric device, that can be affixed to a mundane or magical shield to give it access to additional abilities based on the heraldry shown. This volume has over 30 monstrous visages to attach to your shield... two cursed ones.

179468.name: Never Ask Directions (5E)
179468.description:
From publisher blurb:

When the party finds themselves lost and unable to locate their next adventure, this sidetrek introduces the halfling Carum Half-hand who is all too eager to point them in the right direction. And that direction follows an agenda of his own...

This short 12-page sidetrek is compatible with the 5th (and earlier "classic") editions of Dungeons & Dragons. It is intended for a party of 5 characters (levels 2 - 4) and can be incorporated into any setting. Each encounter features a tactical map and the necessary stat blocks for all creatures involved, so no rulebook page-flipping.

A quick and easy plug-in piece for when the party has strayed too far from their initial quest, Never Ask Directions can fill in the "blank spaces" on your campaign map when the party goes right when they should have headed left.

179469.name: Orcus In Odill
179469.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Cult of Orcus holding weekly services where victims are ritually tortured, and dozens of citizens attend with apparent impunity. Isn’t this what the Inquisition exists for? Or what about the local forces for good or, at least, order? How bad a place is Odill to tolerate this sort of activity? A DnD 5th edition adventure for 1-8 5th level characters. This is the second episode of the Orcus in Odill Saga.

179470.name: Treasures of Orcus
179470.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Cult of Orcus’s book of secrets documents the likely location of the cult’s treasure hoard. What is protecting it is less clear. Are the heroes brave (or foolhardy) enough to make a play for the treasure? A Dungeons and Dragons 5th edition adventure for 1-8 5th level characters. This is the third episode of the Orcus in Odill Saga.

179471.name: Retribution of Orcus
179471.description:
From publisher blurb:

Cults don’t sit idly while adventurers work to eliminate them. The Cult of Orcus in Odill is faced with an existential threat from a group of meddling adventurers who have inspired other threats to coalesce against the Cult. It is time for the Cult to strike back. Can the heroes thwart the cults attempt to eliminate their enemies? A Dungeons and Dragons 5th edition adventure for 1-8 5th level adventures. This is the fourth episode in the Orcus in Odill series.

179472.name: Regime Change
179472.description:
From publisher blurb:

The temple destroyed, its treasure looted, and its counterattack thwarted, the Cult of Orcus in Odill is on its last legs. One night of action could finish it off, and at this opportune moment a questionable ally proposes a plan that could radically alter Odill’s culture. A Dungeons and Dragons 5th edition adventure for 1-8 5th level characters. This is fifth (and final?) episode in the Orcus in Odill Series.

179473.name: Odill Campaign Guide
179473.description:
From publisher blurb:

Odill: a city on the edge. Rife with corruption, slavery, cults, drug dealers, and sadism – otherwise classified as a city ripe for adventurers. An environment suitable for PCs level 5-8.

179474.name: Drow Necromancy
179474.description:
From publisher blurb:

What drives some to leave the safety of their communities and start along the path of adventure. Maybe it is something in their background that compels them; maybe it is the lure of treasure; maybe it is just a curious map. Farjvad is a Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition adventure for 1-8 1st level characters. It is the first episode in the Drow Conspiracy.

179475.name: The Drow Outpost
179475.description:
From publisher blurb:

The pursuit of the insidious drow necromancer has lead the PCs deep into the forest. Is this a small drow incursion, or the start of something much broader and more threatening? Only a group of hardy adventurers can discover the truth. A Dungeons and Dragons 5th edition adventure for 1-8 2nd level PCs.

179476.name: Drow Allies
179476.description:
From publisher blurb:

It appears the casual raiding on the village of Farjvad was just the tip of a deeper conspiracy. In the aftermath of the raid on the drow outpost, hostile activity from various brigands based in the forest has spiked. Nobles turn angrily towards the PCs to resolve what they have started. A DnD 5th edition adventure for 1-8 3rd level characters. Episode 3 in the Drow Conspiracy Epic.

179477.name: Fealty to the Drow
179477.description:
From publisher blurb:

St. Aurelius was a peaceful, prosperous, and productive coastal town with a reputation for friendliness to travelers. But in the span of days, the atmosphere has changed dramatically. Several days ago, Count Arsens gave a brief statement acknowledging fealty to the drow, and hasn’t been seen since. Strangers are shunned. Where there was once a ribald nightlife, the empty streets at night seem foreboding. Something sinister is afoot, and heroes are needed to sort things out. A Dungeons and Dragons 5th edition adventure for 1-8 4th level characters. Episode 4 in the Drow Conspiracy.

179478.name: Drow Consolidation
179478.description:
From publisher blurb:

The drow have taken St. Aurelius, which commands the coast, and most of the lesser villages. But there are some who haven’t surrendered. How will the drow handle these defiant communities? And what will the heroes do? A Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition adventure for 1-8 5th level PCs. Episode 5 in the Drow Conspiracy Epic.

179479.description:
Gnomes, assemble! The factory is in dire need of your skills on the assembly line. Roll dice to amass parts, build components, and be the first gnome to finish their work and go home!

Of course, your co-gnomes won't mind if you borrow some of their parts and use your components to improve your work and mess up theirs, right?
179479.name: Cogs in a Machine
boardgamepodcastepisode: Vox Republica 098: BFIG, The Big Friendly Indie Giant

179480.name: Poetica Mundi
179480.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Grand Stair stretches behind the scenes of the multiverse,
The Doors upon its unfathomably vast span leading the way to gossamer worlds of limitless variety and infinite possibility. Poetica Mundi is a realm where poetry itself is the foundation of reality – where rhyming phrase beat laser rays...

There once was a gossamer realm,
With poetical force at the helm,
In delicate prose,
They spun weals and woes,
And nursed every ash, oak, and elm.

The waves and the wind and the hills,
Shift as pentameter spills,
These lyrical words,
Sing brightly as birds,
A manifestation of wills.

Sometimes it is madness, be sure,
Banality's bane is its cure,
When poetry's pouring,
Never tis boring,
Wide wonders drip wet with allure.

179481.name: Five Jewelry
179481.description:
From publisher blurb:

Need some great magic items for your Pathfinder game; well Avalon Games is here to help. Each issue of the Avalon's Mystic Treasures series will focus on five new magical items for any Pathfinder games. Each item comes with a full description, powers and cost, as well as history and adventure hooks. All you need to do is drop them into your game and watch your players squeal with delight.

Each issue will showcase news items and new treasures, so get each and every issue and add to your magical collection.

179482.name: Links 2003: Championship Edition
179482.description:
User Summery

The final version in the Links series of golf games for the PC. Introduced free swing style play as well as retaining 2-click and 3-click styles.

Contains the 6 courses that came with the original Links 2003 game. Cabo del Sol, Mexico; GLENEAGLES, Scotland; RTJ Golf Trail's Cambrian Ridge, U.S.; Kauri Cliffs, New Zealand; The Tribute at Otsego Club, U.S. and the Fictional Skeleton Coast, Africa.
Also contains 26 courses from Links 2003 championship courses add on.

179483.name: 9 y medio
179483.description:
In 9 y medio (9 and a half), each player will beat the opponents in a "gambler game".

The players should get 9 1/2 or near it for beat their opponents. A player will win if all players are eliminated (losing all their coins), or when all rounds are played and who has more coins get the victory.

This game is a "re-version" of Las siete y media

179484.name: Primary Pounce
179484.description:
(Summarized from the rules. Published by Neil A. Kjos Music Co.)

Similar to "Slap Jack" this is an educational card game for 2-8 players to help learn music keys, signatures and chords.

To start the game, the deck of Cat KEY cards are shuffled and set aside and then the Major KEY SIGNATURE cards, the Primary CHORD cards, and the WILD Mouse cards are shuffled together and dealt evenly among players. A Cat KEY card is turned over to show what key the players are in, and which primary chords and key signatures they are looking for.

Players take turns flipping over the top card from their deck and placing it in the central discard pile until the flipped card shows a Major KEY SIGNATURE or a Primary CHORD card belonging to the key of the Cat KEY card, then players race to "pounce" on it by slapping it with their hand. The first to slap correctly adds the discard pile to his deck and then play continues. If someone incorrectly slaps, he has to give a card from his deck to each other player.

The player who can collect the entire deck (or a majority, if playing with a time limit) is the winner!

179485.name: Monsters & Slayers
179485.description:
From the back of the book

If you are looking for a role-playing game with more realism without burying you with charts, you've finally found it!
'It's 537 A.D. The British Isles have been freed of the Roman Conquerors, so naturally the Celtic Tribes have gone back to their traditional pastime of warring amongst themselves...To complicate matters, all of the monsters and 'Faerie' races of fable, myth and legend are still very much alive!

Monsters and Slayers is different from anything you have ever seen!

179486.name: Jurassic World: The Game
videogamehonor: 2015 CVA Best Game on the Go Nominee
179486.description:
Return to Isla Nublar with the creators of the smash hit Jurassic Park™ Builder for your next adventure: Jurassic World™: The Game, the official mobile game based on this summer’s epic action-adventure. Bring to life more than 50 colossal dinosaurs from the new film and challenge your opponents in earth-shaking battles. Construct the theme park of tomorrow in this unrivaled build-and-battle dinosaur experience.

In order to build a winning Battle Arena team, you’ll need to design the most efficient and effective park, one that will allow your dinosaurs to thrive and evolve. Discover new and amazing species of dinosaurs by acquiring surprise-filled card packs. Join Owen, Claire and your favorite characters from the film as, daily, you feed and genetically enhance your dinosaurs. Now that the park is open, it’s time to make Jurassic World™ your own!

Source: The Publisher Website.

179487.name: My Favorite Carrera RS Trick Taking Game
179487.description:
My favorite Carrera RS is a trick-taking card game themed on car racing. There are six kinds of cards (numbered from 1 to 5, with two kinds of "4" cards), speed chips, fuel chips, and victory tokens.

At the beginning of the round, each player is dealt six cards and five fuel chips. Like typical trick-taking games, the first player leads by playing a card from his/her hand and other players play one by one. The number on the played card represents the speed of the player's racing car. When playing the card, the player has the option to increase the speed of the car by paying a fuel chip(s) and/or a speedy chip(s). Usually, the fastest car wins the trick, but the tricky part is that the value of "4" and "5" cards become all 0s if there is any "1" card played in the trick.

Players also have the option of playing his/her card face-down, giving up the trick but receiving (possible multiple number of) fuel chips from the supply as compensation. Another way to receive a fuel chip is to play a "2" card. But be aware that a player can store a maximum of five fuel chips. Meanwhile, a speed chip is awarded to the player who wins the trick. This means that the player who wins earlier tricks becomes more advantageous for the later tricks.

The most important trick is the last (6th) trick, since only the player who wins the last trick receives a victory token. The player who earns the most victory tokens after a certain number of rounds is the winner of the game.

179488.description:
Using the Napoleonic version of the March into Battle system, this game portrays the Battle of Ligny in a furious, fast moving three turn game. Part of a group of mini-games on the battles of the Waterloo campaign, with Quatre Bras and La Belle Alliance.

In this system, units not just take physical losses but will become ineffective from fatigue and disorder long before they run out of men - unless you, in command, can manage them effectively and maintain their edge.

Map scale: 1km per hex
Unit scale: divisions, 1000 men per strength point
Time scale: 3.5 hours per turn
179488.name: Ligny

179489.description:
Objective: Gain most money

On an outer and inner circuit each player moves forward, based on a die roll. Ending on spaces with symbols follow instructions printed into the lid. Crossing the money pot in the centre of the board: pay for it. Landing on: get it all.
179489.name: Pinke Pinke Schwein gehabt

179490.name: Frag mich was!
179490.description:
Objective: Gain most of the cards by finding correct answers

The game contains 32 question cards (on rhyme) and 32 answer cards. The answer cards are distributed among the players. Players take turns drawing a question card. The player with the matching answer card must respond, otherwise each player may give the right answer gaining the card.

Frag mich was! has elements of Bezzerwizzer.

179491.description: Lembitu: Heavy Cavalry, an expansion for the Lembitu board game, consists of twenty castles that can be used as fortifications, along with six knights; when two blank sides are rolled with the dice of one color, reinforcements arrive for those enemy forces and one knight is placed in front of the chain of enemy units.
179491.name: Lembitu: Heavy Cavalry

179492.name: Scooby-Doo! Amazing Chase Game
179492.description: Each player gets a Scooby-Doo! eraser mover to use in this exciting race to the finish. The special decoder helps you find the snacks you need to zoom ahead. but watch out for the monsters who will set you back. Special game board spaces can be used with smart phones for augmented reality interaction!

179493.name: Legends of Rakasa: Fordra
179493.description:
Legends of Rakasa is a sandbox style (open gameplay structure) game with hunting, crafting, battling, puzzle cracking, and more. The game box is magically packed full of endless adventures.

Legends of Rakasa: Fordra introduces players to the world of Rakasa through Five Introductory Chapters. After players play through those first five chapters, players can go on to create their own unique adventures, or go to the Trivatch.com Forums page to check out game types others are creating.

The game is played on tiles (some holding decks representing the Roads, the Ocean, and the Forest). While seeking to complete different objectives, players hunt across Rakasa by moving their player tokens to the different locations and battle creatures using their player equipment. Players use the parts of defeated creatures to upgrade their equipment. Though upgrading isn't ever the main objective in the Introductory Five Chapters, players are much more likely to succeed in their adventures with stronger equipment.

Along with hunting, crafting, and battling using the cards in Rakasa, players perform different actions using Rakmin, a mini puzzle game included in Legends of Rakasa. Rakmin consist of small tiles and dice. The Rakmin puzzle system is used for actions such as tracking down something or unlocking items.

Five Chapter Story cards guide players through the introductory chapters of Rakasa. The events of these chapters play out over the space of roughly three days in Rakasa. Time passes, hour by hour each turn. Day turns to night and night to day as the events of the chapters unfold. Players may decide to work together cooperatively or work in competition with each other throughout all of the chapters.

The Introductory Five Chapters can be played as individual game instances (each consisting of 30 minutes to an hour of gameplay). The chapters can be played as a set of sequential events, with players progressing their equipment through the chapters. Players can also jump straight into a chapter without playing previous chapters by starting with general gear that matches the difficulty level of the game at that point in the Introductory Five Chapters. After playing through the standard chapters of Legends of Rakasa: Fordra, players will be ready to venture off and create legends of their own!

179494.name: Wardenhale: Gambling Den
179494.description:
From publisher blurb:

"Wardenhale, the city with a thousand names. City of Shadows. City of Trade, City of Justice. Wardenhale is like every city, and yet like no other"

Wardenhale Gambling Den is a printable dungeon floorplan compatible with any RPG/Dungeon-Crawl game. It can be used as a standalone gameboard, or combined with any same-scale tileset. As part of the Wardenhale range, it can be combined with other maps in the set to make a huge city area.

Description:
From the outside, the building seems no different to countless others in the city of Wardenhale. In fact, if you were to enter the building you would simply find the offices of Dalor and Son: Import & Export Services and be asked to be on your way.

However, if you knew the right people, you'd be shown through the back door and into the real business here - gambling. Patrons wager their livelihoods on the throw of a dice or the turn of a card, and if you are in the mood you can venture downstairs and bet on one of the illegal fights that takes place in the arene down there.

Boxing fights, knife fights, bear baiting - it all happens in the Wardenhale Gambling Den

179495.name: Sink or Swim
179495.description:
From publisher blurb:

The second of two short solos written by teenager Dylan Leng - this one a case of piracy on the high seas.

Seize command of a gun-laden vessel - or suffer the perils of the life of a desperado.

Yo ho ho and a bottle of Kraken rum...

179496.name: Shrats and Boglins and Trolls: Oh My
179496.description:
From publisher blurb:

The first of two short solos written by teenager Dylan Leng - this one edited and reworked by Mad Roy Cram.

Go on! See how many PCs you can lose in one adventure!

179497.name: Dungeon World GM Screen
179497.description:
From publisher blurb:

This product contains four pdfs, with twelve letter-sized panels each. Two are black and white, and the other two are in color. One of each set has background art. You get all four pdfs, allowing you to choose which ones you want to print.

The 12 panels feature information on:

The GM (principles, moves, when to make a move, etc)
Making Monsters (complete section)
Common dungeon gear, services, meals, and transport
The entire treasure table
First Session & Fronts
General Equipment, Weapon, and Armor tags
All of the Basic and Special Moves
Steading tags and making every kind of steading
Updating the campaign map
Making hirelings and hireling skills




Everything has a page reference, making it easy to find it in the book in case you need to dig deeper (and the panel doesn't already feature the e

179498.name: Chunky Fighters: Franck Choillard
179498.description: Chunky Fighters: Franck Choillard is the twelfth expansion to Chunky Fighters. The expansion comes with the dice and card for the patriot. This fighter has the power of Camembert (yes, the cheese) to lower all opponent's rolled die rolls by 1 while brandishing his Camembert. He can only Dodge when doing so.

179499.name: Chunky Fighters: Aimé Rikain
179499.description: Chunky Fighters: Aimé Rikain is the eleventh expansion to Chunky Fighters. The expansion comes with the dice and card for the cowboy. This fighter has the power of Ambidexterity (he may both attack and cure himself during the same turn) and gets +1 Damage during Standoffs.
